pros:
I've been at PCH for two years, and I'm still as happy with the orgnization as I was when I started, and everything was new and shiny! 

I really love what I do. I'm given the freedom/flexibility to do my job, and I'm so thankful to work in this enviornment. 

It's beeh harder for us to feel connected due to the COVID year, but the hosptial and leadership has gone above and beyond anyones expectations. Not one employee had to experience a layoff or furlough. We were redeployed into other areas, but if they could not find work for us, all employees still recived a full paycheck. Not one ofther hosptial in the valley provided this type of pay protection plan. 

Employees who were dealing with immense pressure and stress, were provided resources to help manage through the personal crisis. And, as a result, there is now a full time EAP counsellor onsite to meet with employees. 

The SVP of HR was dilligent in having weekly huddles with all staff, and he would keep us informed on what the status of the hospital was during this uncertain time. Those weekly huddles were and still are so important to the staff. It felt like a life line to connect with the other members of the team.
cons: When we were onsite, the work enviornment is a too crowded and noisy - no privacy during calls, and we are on the phone 90% of the day. Some behaviors need to be addressed, and some members of managment choose to ignore the bad behavior instead of dealing with the employee.

pros: Great place to work where the statement that, "We are here for the children" is lived and demonstrated by everyone from support staff, nursing, physicians, and even the Executive Leadership Team. The facility is outstanding and the work environment is very friendly and positive.  The organization is growing rapidly with new opportunities continually occurring.  The stated goal is to be one of the top, if not the top, pediatric hospital in the Nation, and I can honestly say that action is being taken to make this a reality instead of just idle words.  PCH so far has made me feel as very valued member of the organization.
cons: A lot of growth is occurring so things are quite busy at times.  Change is occurring with this growth which I can see is frustrating for some who do not like change, but we can't become the best without challenging ourselves and changing to becoming better.  Depending on where one lives in the valley the commute can be long (that is a matter of perspective to some depending on what you are use to), so if moving here be aware the commute factor when selecting a place to live.

job_title: Registered Nurse, BSN in Phoenix, AZ
pros: resources, unit cleanliness, new technology
cons: they expect high quality care from ICU nurses while paying them the same rate as floor nurses.

pros: People who choose to work here don't do it for the money, they do it because they genuinely want to help children and it shows. Child Life department dedicated to normalizing the hospital experience for kids truly does a good job. Lots of donated toys, fun activities to take kids' minds off of their illness, visiting athletes and celebrities create high energy.
cons:
I have worked in 2 very different, role-wise, departments in the last 5 years and wish I could still believe that' it's "100% For Children" as claimed. Yes it's a business 1st and foremost or it wouldn't remain open and keep serving people, but employee satisfaction and fair compensation are needing considerable improvement. 
-Frequent changes in workflow
-Salaries not comparable to other like jobs in the market
-Hiring a disproportionate of new RNs as they are less expensive but at the detriment of not having safe staffing 
-Most positions have very little room for advancement
-Management plays favorites

review_title: If you want to be a Babysitter....
job_title: Behavioral Health Technician in Phoenix, AZ
pros: Working with the kids is a plus. There are some days where you walk out of working a 12 hour shift feeling like you might have done someone some good. However, those days are few and far between. PCH does have great benefits if you have kids and they have an amazing tuition reimbursement plan for those that are going to school or plan to.
cons: You feel like you are a babysitter for most of the time. Seeing that the BHT's spend most of the time with the kids during the day, talking with them, observing them, running groups with them I find it a little degrading that we are not shown the same kind of respect that the nurses are given. The BHT's all (or most) have degrees and most are in school for their Masters. I feel like management does not respect and acknowledge all the amazing skills and talent that most of the staff have. The late and absent policy needs to change also. If you are just a few minutes late you are considered absent and you only get so many days you can be absent before they fire you. So don't be late even a minute late!

review_title: Good culture, very fast pace environment
pros: Awesome working for the children
cons: High stress, fast paced and lack of training

job_title: (Prefer Not to State) in Phoenix, AZ
pros:
Last year there: 2006 
 Care is excellent!  They saved a family member's life!  Most staff members are well educated and trained.  Most Docs are very talented!  Food is good...ice cream is great...they feed night staff!!!  Housekeeping works hard to keep the place clean. Having translators in house (Spanish speaking) is a tremendous help in patient care!
cons: The nurses don't like staff with "lesser titles" (scrub tech, lab tech, ED tech, Unit coordinators) with higher levels of education.  They feel threatened, and will not use the additional knowledge to their advantage.  ONLY nurses are "allowed" to be better educated and experienced. Perhaps they don't like staff working through school in non-nursing programs.  Lots of cliques and back stabbing!  Worked there 5yrs, left on good terms, cannot get my former position back!  Have applied for 4 years!

job_title: Certified Medical Assistant (CMA) in Phoenix, AZ
pros: lovely staff, clean and well organized
cons: unsteady and honestly quite understaffed

pros: I really enjoy working at PCH, truly. My patients are the best and the reason I stay.
cons: As much as I love PCH and would like to never leave here the pay is absolutely horrible for nurses and techs. After taxes and insurance we make almost nothing compared to any other hospital in AZ. The critical care areas don’t get paid more and the turn over of bedside staff is horrible! Also, probably the most aggravating part is that if you work here you can expect the most ridiculous pay raise system ever. However, if you come in with experience you make way more. So basically it doesn’t matter about how many years of service you have put in at the hospital if you leave and then come back you make way more. So they basically push you out because nobody can live off this ridiculous pay.

review_title: So far so good in Pharmacy
pros: Everyone in my department (pharmacy) has been welcoming. I feel very supported while getting used to my new role and adjusting to the pediatric world. The director and ops manager are visible. So far parking is much improved from my prior hospital with the exception of the 1000 shift - which is VERY difficult to find a place. As for the hospital as a whole, the people here are quite friendly. I got a bit turned around when coming in for my pre-employment screening and one of the employees walked me practically halfway across campus to get me to the right building. I really appreciate only having to staff every third weekend instead of every other weekend and pay rate is very competitive.
cons: It's a minor thing, but I miss getting employee discounts in the cafeteria (I used to be able to fill a large work-branded plastic cup for $0.50, but here it costs $1.60). Parking for certain shift times (see above). Unfortunately, my department has several people out/going to be out for maternity leave, so there is a lot of shift swapping and people aren't always aware that I'm going to be training with them.

review_title: I really love coming to work E V E R Y D A Y!
pros: My team is really a team! I feel like I make a difference in what I do everyday.  People you see are smiling walking down the hospital and if they aren't they have a reason to be sad ~ but what I do can make a difference.  I believe the managers, doctors and HR team strive to hire the best so that the children and families receive the best care from start to finish.  One of the best cafeterias I have been to.  Reasonable costs and lots of variety to choose from.  Hospital Orientation is one of the best orientations I have seen where upper management takes pride and ownership of attending each and every one to give the exact same message of 100% for the kids and show that they value EVERY new hire regardless of what your job is going to be!
cons: My commute is a little longer than I would like it to be, but that doesn't mean I can't move closer in the future.

job_title: Medical Laboratory Scientist in Phoenix, AZ
pros: PCH treats everybody like family.  From the moment that I had my first interview through my first month with this organization I have only felt like this is where I have meant to be my entire career. Every person from the janitorial staff, through security all the way to the CEO are passionate for the children that they serve. I genuinely feel that I have an opportunity to assist the children who visit this institution, and I feel that the families have the support that they need as well.  Even though I have only been with this company for a short while I receive positive input when I am in public with my scrubs or badge that shows my connection with a loved local hospital system. Many people have had their lives touched in some aspect by the work done at Phoenix Children's. I know mine has on multiple levels. I look forward to the opportunities to advance with PCH as they continue to grow and I am thankful for the opportunities to serve our future generations.
cons: I have yet to identify any "con" in working with this company.

review_title: It can be fun but 90% of the times it’s repetitive and boring. Feels like a errands boy/girl. PCH as a hospital is great
pros:
• This job is what you make of it. It can be fun but you have to put yourself out there because you’re not really there to help patients. 

• Co-Workers are great, and supervisors are ok too. 

• Cafeteria food is great too! 

• Great atmosphere
cons:
• Unlike outpatient clinics where you are hands on, this job is mostly cleaning, restocking, and fetching equipment. 

• Not hands on at all

• It can be overwhelming at times because the demand can be high. There’s about 15+ therapists and 3 rehab techs. 

• You don’t really help patients as a rehab tech your job is to clean toys (this is the main job and focus), stock linens, and get equipment. If your not doing one of those 3 things there’s not much to do. 

• I don’t recommend this job for anyone that wants to be hands on with patients or anyone that hate repetitiveness. 

• Pay is hourly and experience doesn’t matter, you get paid    based on the average pay for the position in your area. No raise either.

review_title: Low salary with little opportunity for advancement, but wonderful atmosphere for the patients
job_title: Clinical Nurse II in Phoenix, AZ
pros: I have worked at PCH for six years as an RN. Kiddos feel "at home" at PCH. The new, main tower and the renovation of most of the East tower are bright, colorful, and inviting to the children and families in their times of stress. Overall, good benefits, including tuition reimbursement.
cons: Senior management is not visible to staff on a regular basis. High staff turnover rates in some areas.. Salary is lower than that for comparable positions at other local hospitals, especially considering this is a specialized field. There is currently no nursing clinical ladder, so little room for advancement, and certifications and advanced degrees are encouraged, but not financially rewarded.  Human resources department ineffective in resolving certain issues, such as workplace harrassment/bullying.

job_title: Financial Planning and Analysis in Phoenix, AZ
pros: Great benefits and work life balance.
cons: Horribly slow systems, oppressive management style with little room for growth or upward mobility, holiday time is not separated from PTO and they pay on a 2 week pay period, so if you are coming from a bi-monthly pay cycle, you get less on every paycheck. They have big meetings showing everyone how there is room to grow and positions open and then you get reprimanded and demerited if you ask. The politics are off the charts and the climate changes with each CFO.

pros: The hospital itself is great, as well as the doctors and most of the staff. The PTO and benefits are good and there are satellite clinics/ urgent cares to give you options on location and hours.
cons: The radiology department has a very understaffed x-ray department and a revolving door of employees there. There is a bit of pressure to pick up shifts so supervisors/leads never have to, and this has been going on for years. Also, if you choose to work at a satellite location you still will be expected to pick up call days at the hospital.

job_title: Patient Access Specialist in Phoenix, AZ
pros: Love the job.  Co-workers are very helpful. Management is accessible.
cons: Training needs to be more hands on.   I actually trained myself after the third day.  Hard copy hand outs help but there are so many additional steps in the processes that new-hire is not aware of.   Leads are available but are also working their accounts.   Within the first month, employee is already expected to meet goals.  Hard to do when you are still learning the program particulars and processes.

review_title: No Transparency No Respect Great Mission
pros: Everyone who works at PCH truly believes in the Mission to improve the health of children. Benefits are reasonable. Food is Fantastic.
cons: It is a top down managed organization at the point of absurd. If someone leaves a position you need the CEO's permission to hire the replacement. The CEO is a good business man but a poor leader - he is known for his temper and actually yelling at his C suite. It is a very "them and us" culture between providers and administration with littletrust or respect in either direction. Leadership turns over on their own or with help about every 2 years and there is so little middle management that the directors and managers are burnt to a crisp. PCH has excellent vision for  change but not the culture or infrastructure to reach it at this point.

pros: I’m only neutral about this review for the children I see on a daily basis. They’re the reason PCH is around. The gratitude and fulfillment I get from helping children is heartwarming.
cons: Where do I begin... management is poor in listening and implementing action to your concerns, and is very political when it comes to raises, promotions, and CS’s. Very poor communication between upper management which leads to confusion. ALSO if you plan on working in the EAST OR building they don’t pay any differential for taking call as the main OR staff does. Nothing ever gets addressed, mostly swept under a rug and forgot about. Dr’s are very passive aggressive and childlike; will gossip about you to other providers and smile in your face. Also to mention the pay is significant lower than many other competitors in the Phoenix metro areas. Anyways I think y’all get it

pros: Great teamwork, supportive leadership and career growth opportunities. What better mission than to help children and families.  It doesn't matter if you are on the clinical or administrative side, you know each day you are making a difference.
cons: There is no such thing as perfect but an 80/20 split is pretty close. Some administrative processes and work culture  are outdated.  Need to know how to create your own work-life balance as it is not embedded into the culture here which creates some burnout.

review_title: Dynamic, fast paced, exciting and meaningful place to work
pros:
Knowing you helped children and families in their time of need is much more rewarding than just helping someone else's profit margin
This organization is GROWING - PCH has seen 25% growth for the last 4 years in a row. 
This is not a "we've always done it that way" hospital - everyone gets a chance to provide ideas about ways things can work better and management listens
This is an exciting place to work - the hospital is getting lots of national recognition, it's growing and there are always new clinics getting started.
cons: Some people want things to stay the way they always were - and this place is growing and changing...some of my friends complain its not like it used to be.

review_title: Not the best place to work
job_title: Clinical RN II in Phoenix, AZ
pros: Prior to the new hospital being built: Worked with amazing staff, that's what kept a lot of us there. Child Life was awesome. Some of the physicians were amazing. An interesting place to work, never a dull moment. Met some awesome and wonderful children/families.
cons: Floor manager unorganized. During my 5 years of employment the floor manager was switched 3 times. Upper management not involved. Unsafe working conditions and high acuity. Often understaffed and concerns never addressed. Underpaid. Under-appreciated. The staff that needed reprimanding never got in trouble yet continued to pose a threat to the patients and entire organization. Employees not treated well.

pros: The Volunteer Services personnel are wonderful to work with as are many of the staff. It is a joy and privilege to work with the children and their families. The hospital setting is inviting to children and helps allay their fears. Special TV stations are established for patients of various ages so they can watch cartoons, Disney movies, or something for the adolescent.
cons: Staff is often over worked with limited opportunity for assistance on many floors. Lateral violence is present in some areas, cafeteria is closed from 7m to 10pm which is often during the time when parents can step away to take a break and eat something or just unwind from the emotional strain they are under. HR is slow to hire and often does not update hiring status for months at a time or loses applicants information.

job_title: Patient Access Representative in Phoenix, AZ
pros: The hospital is a beautiful facility and a very well-known name in the Arizona community. The medical staff is highly skilled and often a pleasure to work with. Pay is competitive and the benefits are great. Most of the people you work with truly love kids and enjoy making the environment positive and friendly.
cons: The healthcare systems used are extremely outdated and clunky. There is a ton of paperwork and most of it is repetitive or redundant. It can be difficult to get any new changes approved. Management is mostly unavailable. A huge con is that there are no annual raises. Everyone gets a cost-of-living adjustment and mine was only 11 cents!

review_title: Great patient care, poor consideration of staff
pros: The patient care is top notch, and people are dedicated. PCH provides great care, and the people you work with are, for the most part, fantastic, knowledgeable, and committed to doing the best job possible.
cons: IT leadership has little to no regard for people or professional development. There is very little vision towards making the IT infrastructure more efficient. It is more about putting bandaids on bandaids and incremental improvements than actually having a vision. This results in armies of back end staff fixing errors created by front end staff. There are two EMRs in use, and one is text-based and the other allows you to enter garbage DOBs.

pros: The Foundation has a wonderful culture and a great Leader in Steve Schnall. If you want to wake up and enjoy what you do each day then this is a wonderful place to work. Benefits and pay are reasonable.
cons: This job requires working many hours and often under a ton of stress. The foundation also has little room for advancement and often times there is a large turnover due to working people to the bone.

job_title: Certified Medical Coder in Phoenix, AZ
pros: Competitive pay, secure parking, cafeteria is pretty good too.  Management communicates goals and issues, asks for feedback and is open and able to be approached.   After a few months of meeting quality and productivity standards you are able to work from home.   My supervisors are not right on top of me 24/7, everyone is treated like they are adults.  There are company promotions and team building things going on every few weeks.
cons: This is a corporate environment, thats not always a bad thing, it's just the way it is.  The office has no windows( thats fine with me, I don't go to work to spend time looking out the windows).  The office can be almost totally silent at times with everyone working, I know that can be an issue with some people,  lots of people bring headphones and MP3 plyers.

review_title: If you're not a director, doctor or executive, don't count on much.
pros: Everyone is passionate about helping sick or injured children. The nice new building is great if you actually work in that one.
cons: Overworked, underpaid, have had years without raises. There's no transparency and if you aren't in a position of power, you are pretty much just a workhorse. Technology is way behind, no EHR, everyone works in a silo and employee satisfaction is lower than average. Although the new building is pretty, it's not child-friendly. Honestly have never worked with more petty people in my life.

job_title: Network Engineer II in Phoenix, AZ
pros: Everyone from the top down shares the same commitment to excellent care and putting kids first in everything.  Great people to work with.  Constantly finding new ways to give back to kids with volunteering food drives and other activities.  These are not required but feels great to be part of.  Working in the IT department specifically has been great.  Lots of motivation to do your very best.  Very collaborative effort across each team.  Fantastic leaders also.  I've been surprised to have someone engage me in conversation about how I like working here and personal responses then find out they are one of the vice presidents.  People truly care about you.
cons: I can't think of any honestly.

pros: Can't beat the mission. We care about our patients and do what is right for them. High quality care for a wide range of conditions. Great benefits.
cons: Some members of leadership are bullies. Every single new position must be approved by the CEO. No EVP or SVP will do anything without the CEOs approval, so progress is very slow. CEO has hired 2 of his kids and they move up quickly with promotions. VP turnover is way too high.

job_title: Patient Access Representative in Glendale, AZ
pros: Working with great families, children, and for a WONDERFUL cause. When I first started to work for Phoenix children's I felt honored to work long side great people and a help everyone attitude.
cons: BAD Managers in the administrative department. I went to my Patient Access Manager after seeing HIPPA violations and having to work 12 hour shifts with no break. lunch, or any food during the entire day. Only to told I was a "Trouble maker" and dismissed.

job_title: Infrastructure Engineer II in Phoenix, AZ
pros: Just an amazing place to work. IT leadership is top notch, simply the best! From the CIO down leadership does everything in their power to ensure the teams have everything they need to meet and exceed the expectations of the business. Technology is new, pace is fast, management knows IT, moving forward and keeping ahead of the curve. Freedom to stop, take a look around and question process to make systems better as well as make suggestions to improve efficiency. Professionalism, hard work pays off here!
cons: IT department is quickly outgrown provided work space.

job_title: Registered Nurse, BSN in Phoenix, AZ
pros: I started in April as a new grad RN.  The new grad RN program is wonderful!  The first month consists of skills labs, as well as a ton of lectures taught by the nurse educators in each department.  Felt like every topic is covered so I felt very comfortable starting on my floor.  Starting in the end of April/ early May, you begin to have shifts on your floor that you were hired on, starting with a preceptor.  Benefits are great, extremely happy working here!
cons: Hiring process took a long time.  Applied online and had an employee referral, and that took a few months just to get a call for an interview.

review_title: not what it cracked up to be....
pros: Good resume builder. Beautiful facilities. Tuition reimbursement programs (if you are a nursing student only). Takes a while to get accepted as a newbie, but it can be done.
cons: Very clique-ish. It is also very difficult to move on up or change status after you have been hired. I have been PRN and cannot even move to part-time, as friends of friends are being hired as a favor. It is all about who you know.

pros: High Acuity, Level 1 Trauma Hospital, many different areas of nursing to practice in, every seems to like what they do, the tools are there to get the job done.
cons: The pay is terrible, not a very pro-nurse hospital, at PCH the nursing profession isn't as highly respected as it is at other large pediatric facilities, this was evident during nurse appreciation week, the benefits, compensation, and during reviews.

pros: Great opportunities to advance your career. Education is well supported. The only place you really want to bring your children to for care. Whenever I mention that I work at PCH, the response is always positive.
cons: Benefits are competitive, but have definitely decreased over the years. We now pay a lot more for a lot less. That is just our country's reality right now.

job_title: Patient Care Technician in Phoenix, AZ
pros: I love the fact that we get to bond with different families and as staff members of Phoenix  Children's Hospital, we become family to some of the patients.  When you see what some of the patients and the families have to go through during there time of crisis it makes you realize that it is always someone somewhere that has it harder than you and to be grateful of life.
cons: Need more incentives for extra shifts for our busy seasons.

job_title: Outpatient Rehab Services in Phoenix, AZ
pros: You will see the most diverse pediatric population ranging  from cardiac to head trauma to all sorts of rare and  unusual diagnoses.  You will learn a tremendous amount.    You will be able to interact with a variety of physicians and work collaboratively with other therapy providers.  The patients will motivate you every day!
cons: You will do that leaning by yourself without training or support.

review_title: The only place to take your children for serious medical conditions
pros: Amazing place!  Hospital has grown and grown with so many specialties.  Dr's. , Staff, Volunteers all do such great work, and work so hard.  Proud to work here.  Unbelievable life saving miracles do happen here!
cons: Growing very fast, need to catch up with adequate staffing per workload.

pros: Employees are often united in the cause of helping kids. Atmosphere is not your typical hospital and is upbeat and bright. Food is served through the day at a cafeteria or the coffee shop. Retail pharmacy with employee discounts if you use them. Good benefits, for medical.
cons:
No movement once you are in due to high external hiring and buddy hiring practices. High school environment with nursing staff (which includes the physicians) with a cut-throat attitude and lots of bad mouthing each other. I get to see and hear lots as IT (they chatter on and ignore you when you are busy fixing something for them), and the gossiping is nasty. Not much different from other health care places however.
High stress!
You will not move up easily. VP's and Supers are chosen from outside, managers hired as favors for someone's friend or family members. Atmosphere is highly political. You will be treated poorly by most doctors and residents as many of them are treated like celebrities.
Do not bother complaining to HR. Your manager will be informed, whether you want to be confidential or not.
I have yet to see someone in my section able to successfully utilize half the benefits claimed to be available. Favorites of managers get those types of benefits.
There is no PTO exchange system where people can donate PTO directly to a coworker they feel needs it. You will watch many whither, suffer, and have to quit, especially if they have a family. There are no paid FMLA days, vacation, sick leave, and only 3 days of berevement. "100% for Children", unless they are yours.
Sexual harrassment is on the rise in IT. If you are not he type to put out or flirt, you will not be liked as much as those who do. You will also spend lots of time picking up where they leave off, male or female, while in IT, because they are not there for their abilities.
Majority of VPs are business suits, having their degrees in irrelevant fields but, as said, hired because they are someone's friend or family. The bottom line is still king in this "non-profit" company.
If you do not give every month to different charity runs, you will be made to seem like a stick in the mud or a bad-meaning person.
Managers and Supers will make triple figures while you wait for that next paycheck, VPs an unknown amount where they can buy the latest gadgets and trinkets without a thought.

review_title: Great Company - Priorities in the right spot
job_title: Information Technology Manager in Phoenix, AZ
pros: The work Environment is great. Cafeteria is amazing. Co-Workers are super smart. The hospital mission is easy to get behind. The leadership is accountable. The pay is competitive
cons: Your budgeting process and approval process can be a challenge if your purchases are not directly related to the care of patients. (e.g. IT Stuff)

pros:
Benefits! PCH offers one of the best benefits package in the valley! Salaries are fairly competitive but the benefits are a big win! Great  health, dental and vision packages plus 401K with a great match AND tuition reimbursement for many programs. 

Atmosphere! You have to be driven and motivated to work here with an always evolving regulatory culture. It makes the work exciting and you'll never be bored! Plus, being a pediatrics hospital, the staff are super compassionate and and the culture is family oriented. I think the field of pediatrics just naturally draws energetic, kind and compassionate people to these types of organizations.  From the executive level and through all departments, every meeting agenda and discussion is focused on how to provide exceptional care for our patients. There is a team atmosphere here that encompasses all specialties and roles towards improving care. It's a  truly multicultural, multidisciplinary approach towards the pursuit of excellent care and services. I also love that the organization demonstrates equability for job advancements. If you demonstrate exceptional leadership skills, innovative thinking ,  taking initiative,  great communication skills and an ability to bring a team together to work towards a common goal, you will  do well and will fit in with this organization. If you can manage all of this with a great attitude, careful consideration of all of the players and teams involved and with measured response...you're going to be rock star at PCH and you WILL be recognized for contributions to this very special culture.
cons: This certainly is not a con for me but for some it may be: You have to be flexible and ready for change!!! PCH is an organization that is accredited by Joint Commissions and as their requirements evolve, patient safety initiatives evolve, healthcare reimbursements/culture evolves, and federal & state regulations change, you MUST be able to evolve your practices or process as well! You have to be resilient and creative to meet ever changing priorities. You have to be able to take initiative when you see that processes can be enhanced. You have to work well as part of a multidisciplinary team and engage in effective and considerate dialog with a variety of teams. "if you want to go fast, go alone. If you want to go far, go together". No where is that philosophy more true than at PCH.  The work we all do impacts, either directly or indirectly, the care provided to our patients. This is why it is imperative that when progress is being discussed, for any issue, all teams involved in providing that service MUST be able to discuss the barriers and the successful practices that are specific to their department or specialty. Thus when a new program or process is rolled out, it will be effective and efficient for the services impacted by the change. Again, none of this seems like a deficit to me but for some potential applicants, perhaps it is. Working towards and obtaining multidisciplinary buy in, for any project, is consistently practiced at PCH. Again, I love this aspect of working at PCH because it gives me an opportunity to voice my concerns or lend my opinion on new practices that impact my contribution to the overall mission and vision. Finally, again, for me not a weakness but other's may not be too excited about: You will stay busy! There is no such event as a "lazy day" here! You have to be super organized, ready for changing priorities and focused on getting the job done! I've been here for nearly a decade and have never had a "quiet" day. It's all hassle and bustle to meet deadlines, enact change, re-prioritize and to serve the patients, families and colleagues who rely on you for whatever resources  you provide. Every day there is a new challenge or variation or change in practice that needs to be addressed so there is never a dull moment. For me, it's exciting....no two days are the same!

job_title: Manager, Marketing and Communications in Phoenix, AZ
pros: On the outside, the mission and vision of PCH are enough to draw anyone in. On the inside, the medical professionals and the children and families they support are enough to make you stay a lot longer than you probably would have otherwise.
cons:
You want to believe in everything PCH stands for. The hope, healing and healthcare provided to patients and their families should be more than enough to make you love going into the office every day. And even on those days where the politics of it all gets in the way, you hold out hope, because you want to believe in the mission and vision so badly, often times sacrificing your own physical and mental health to do so. I have more fond memories of my time at PCH than I can count, but most of those memories are overshadowed by the toxicity and competitive culture created and enforced by leadership. And now, when I think of PCH, I’m left with a sour taste in my mouth. I departed on my own teams - albeit not great ones - because I felt like I had no choice. If I had stayed at PCH, not only would I have been doing a disservice to an organization I had dedicated six years of my working life to because I was incredibly unhappy, but I would have been doing a disservice to my health. 

Every day I went into the office wanting to do well, often times working upwards of 60-70+ hours/week to check off all of the to-dos, only to repeatedly feel belittled, disrespected and discouraged by whoever my boss was at the time (I had six in six years, and only one switch was by choice ... the others were the results of reorgs or “new opportunities”). I cried more times out of frustration than any employee should. I turned friends and trusted colleagues into competitors, because leadership openly told us we had to “prove our worth to keep our jobs.” Never in my life have I been so discouraged by the person I had become than when I look back at my last few years at PCH. The leadership is toxic, and it starts at the top. Looking back, I had to remind myself on a DAILY basis that I was enough, and most days, I didn’t believe it. Not because I wasn’t enough; I was darn good at my job. But because the leadership at PCH (at least the leadership I experienced) fosters a toxic environment and culture where no matter how successful or kind or honest or hardworking you are, it will never be enough.
